reasons_to_visit.details: February is the heart of the low season in Galway. Experience the city's attractions like the Spanish Arch, Galway City Museum, and Latin Quarter shops with virtually no crowds and find excellent deals on accommodation.
Perfect weather for embracing Galway's legendary pub scene. Enjoy pints by roaring fires, hearty stews, and frequent traditional music sessions in iconic pubs.
Explore Galway's indoor offerings like the Galway City Museum, Galway Cathedral, St. Nicholas' Church, or visit the Atlantaquaria (National Aquarium) in Salthill as escapes from the weather.
Experience the electric atmosphere in Galway pubs when Ireland plays in the Six Nations rugby tournament. A fantastic way to mingle with locals and share the passion.
Towards month's end, look for early spring flowers like snowdrops appearing along the River Corrib or in sheltered spots, hinting at warmer days ahead.
Galway's atmospheric streets, cozy restaurants, and pubs provide a charming backdrop for a Valentine's Day escape.

reasons_to_reconsider.reason: Cold, Very Wet, and Windy Atlantic Weather
reasons_to_reconsider.details: February often brings Galway's coldest, dampest weather, frequently accompanied by strong Atlantic gales and driving rain. High-quality waterproof and windproof gear is non-negotiable.
Daylight is still quite limited, though increasing (sunrise ~8:00 AM, sunset ~5:30 PM by late Feb). Outdoor sightseeing time is restricted.
Boat trips (Aran Islands, Cliffs of Moher cruises) are unlikely to be running or highly weather-dependent. Connemara exploration requires good preparation and tolerance for harsh conditions.
Outside weekend evenings and rugby match days, Galway can feel very quiet, especially mid-week. Some find this peaceful, others may find it too subdued.
Some visitor attractions, smaller shops, or cafes, particularly outside the immediate city centre or in Salthill, might have reduced winter hours or take short closures.

weather.precipitation: Frequent rain and strong winds are highly likely. Overcast days dominate. Average monthly rainfall ~110-130mm. Frost possible.
weather.general_tips: Pack thermal layers, a heavy-duty waterproof and windproof coat, hat, gloves, scarf, and waterproof boots with good grip. Forget the flimsy umbrella.

tourism_level.crowds: Extremely low. Attractions will feel empty. No need to book most restaurants unless it's Valentine's night.
tourism_level.pricing: Lowest season rates for accommodation. Excellent value possible.
tourism_level.overall_atmosphere: Quiet, local, and intimate. Ideal for those seeking authentic pub experiences and uncrowded sightseeing. Can feel bleak in bad weather, cozy indoors.

events_holidays.name: St Brigid's Day Bank Holiday
events_holidays.date: First Monday in February (or Feb 1st if Fri)
events_holidays.description: New public holiday. Some services/shops may close, but pubs and restaurants generally remain open. Check specific attractions.
events_holidays.notes: Minimal impact compared to other bank holidays usually.

events_holidays.name: Six Nations Rugby Screenings
events_holidays.description: Pubs throughout Galway screen matches, especially Ireland games. Expect lively crowds and a great atmosphere.
events_holidays.notes: Popular pubs (e.g., The Skeff, Murty Rabbitts) get packed; arrive early.

events_holidays.name: Valentine's Day
events_holidays.description: Restaurants offer special menus; some pubs may have events. Essential to book popular dining spots well in advance.

unique_experiences.description: Delve into the history and heritage of Galway city and its connection to the sea. Warm, dry, and informative.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Free entry. Allow 1-2 hours. Check opening times (often closed Mondays). Located beside the Spanish Arch.

unique_experiences.activity: Trad Music Session in a Cozy Pub
unique_experiences.where: Latin Quarter / West End (e.g., Tigh Coili, The Crane Bar, Taaffes)
unique_experiences.description: Find a pub with a fireplace and settle in for an evening of authentic live traditional Irish music. The quintessential Galway winter experience.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Check pub schedules; sessions often start around 9/9:30 pm. Arrive early for a good seat, especially on weekends.

unique_experiences.description: Admire the impressive scale and interior mosaics and stained glass of one of Europe's youngest large stone cathedrals.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Offers shelter from the elements. Check opening times around services. Entry usually free, donations welcome.

unique_experiences.activity: Wander the Latin Quarter & West End Shops
unique_experiences.description: Explore the unique independent shops selling crafts, books, jewelry (including Claddagh rings), and clothing, dipping in and out of the weather.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Compact area, easy to navigate. Quieter than other times of year, allowing for relaxed browsing.

weather.precipitation: Still cold, windy, and wet, but the increasing daylight becomes noticeable. Potential for slightly brighter spells between showers.
weather.general_tips: Warm, waterproof, windproof clothing remains crucial. Don't be fooled by hints of spring; winter gear is still needed.

tourism_level.overall_atmosphere: Quietly local. Pubs and indoor venues are the main social focus. Longer days offer slightly more scope for brief outdoor walks if weather allows.

events_holidays.name: Six Nations Rugby Screenings
events_holidays.description: Continued pub screenings if matches are on.
events_holidays.notes: A reliable source of atmosphere on match days.

events_holidays.name: Theatre & Music Gigs
events_holidays.description: Check schedules for Town Hall Theatre, Róisín Dubh, Monroe's Live for plays, comedy, and music acts.
events_holidays.notes: Good indoor entertainment options. Book ahead for specific events.

unique_experiences.activity: Visit the National Aquarium of Ireland (Atlantaquaria)
unique_experiences.description: Explore Ireland's largest native species aquarium, showcasing life from rivers, lakes, and the Atlantic. A great indoor activity.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Located on the Salthill Promenade (bus or long walk). Check winter opening times. Good for families.

unique_experiences.description: Visit the historic medieval heart of Galway city. Admire the architecture and soak in the centuries of history within its walls.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Check opening hours. Offers a quiet refuge. Look for interesting historical features inside.

unique_experiences.activity: Walk along the River Corrib & Canals
unique_experiences.description: Enjoy a walk along the fast-flowing River Corrib or the quieter adjacent canals, spotting swans and observing the city from a different angle.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Wear good footwear. Can be combined with visits to the Cathedral or NUIG campus. Best on a dry, less windy day.

unique_experiences.where: County Mayo (Requires car or limited bus service)
unique_experiences.description: Visit the charming village famous for 'The Quiet Man' film, explore Cong Abbey ruins, and walk the grounds of Ashford Castle.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Check weather forecast carefully. Daylight hours limit exploration time. Best attempted on a rare clear, calm day.
